canonical_explanation.text: Surface chemistry deals with phenomena occurring at surfaces or interfaces. Adsorption is the accumulation of molecular species at the surface rather than in the bulk. The substance adsorbed is the adsorbate and the material on whose surface adsorption occurs is the adsorbent. Physisorption involves weak van der Waals forces, is reversible, has low enthalpy of adsorption (20-40 kJ/mol), is not specific, and forms multilayers. Chemisorption involves chemical bond formation, is irreversible, has high enthalpy (80-240 kJ/mol), is highly specific, and forms a monolayer. Adsorption isotherms describe the variation of adsorption with pressure at constant temperature. The Freundlich isotherm gives x/m = kP^(1/n) where 1/n lies between 0 and 1. The Langmuir isotherm assumes monolayer adsorption on equivalent sites. Catalysis involves substances that alter reaction rates without being consumed. Homogeneous catalysis has catalyst and reactants in the same phase; heterogeneous catalysis has them in different phases. Catalytic action involves adsorption of reactants, formation of intermediates, and desorption of products. Enzyme catalysis is highly specific, shows Michaelis-Menten kinetics, and is affected by temperature, pH, and inhibitors. Colloidal solutions have particle sizes between 1-1000 nm. Colloids are classified as lyophilic (solvent-loving, reversible) and lyophobic (solvent-hating, irreversible). Preparation methods include chemical methods (reduction, oxidation, hydrolysis), electrical disintegration (Bredig's arc method), and peptization. Properties include Tyndall effect (scattering of light), Brownian motion (random zigzag movement), electrophoresis (movement under electric field), and coagulation (settling by addition of electrolytes). Hardy-Schulze rule states that the greater the valency of the flocculating ion, the greater its coagulating power. Emulsions are colloidal systems of two immiscible liquids stabilised by emulsifiers. Oil-in-water (O/W) and water-in-oil (W/O) are the two types. Gels are semi-rigid colloidal systems. Colloids find applications in water purification, photography, medicine, and industry.
rules: Physisorption: van der Waals forces, reversible, multilayer, low ΔH (20-40 kJ/mol); chemisorption: chemical bonds, irreversible, monolayer, high ΔH (80-240 kJ/mol).
Freundlich adsorption isotherm: x/m = kP^(1/n), where 0 < 1/n < 1.
Extent of adsorption increases with increase in surface area and decrease in temperature (for physisorption).
Homogeneous catalysis: catalyst and reactants in same phase; heterogeneous: different phases.
Enzyme catalysis follows Michaelis-Menten kinetics; enzyme activity depends on temperature, pH, and substrate concentration.
Colloidal particles range from 1 nm to 1000 nm; lyophilic colloids are reversible and self-stabilising, lyophobic are irreversible.
Tyndall effect: scattering of light by colloidal particles; Brownian motion: random zigzag movement due to collision with dispersion medium molecules.
Hardy-Schulze rule: coagulating power of an ion increases with its valency.
Electrophoresis: movement of colloidal particles under an electric field towards the oppositely charged electrode.
Emulsions: O/W type (e.g., milk) uses water-soluble emulsifier; W/O type (e.g., butter) uses oil-soluble emulsifier.
Peptization: conversion of a precipitate into a colloidal sol by adding an electrolyte (peptizing agent).

questions.question_text: Adsorption is a:
questions.explanation_correct: Adsorption occurs at the surface of the adsorbent where molecules of the adsorbate accumulate. It is fundamentally a surface phenomenon.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Adsorption involves accumulation of species at a surface or interface, not throughout the bulk. It is neither a nuclear process nor a homogeneous phenomenon — it specifically involves surface interactions.

questions.question_text: The enthalpy of physisorption typically lies in the range:
questions.explanation_correct: Physisorption involves weak van der Waals forces, so the enthalpy of adsorption is low, typically in the range of 20–40 kJ/mol.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 80–240 kJ/mol is the range for chemisorption, not physisorption. The higher values (200–400, 400–800) are far too large for the weak van der Waals interactions involved in physisorption.

questions.question_text: Which type of adsorption involves the formation of chemical bonds between adsorbate and adsorbent?
questions.explanation_correct: Chemisorption (chemical adsorption) involves the formation of chemical bonds between the adsorbate and the surface of the adsorbent, making it highly specific and generally irreversible.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Physisorption involves only weak van der Waals forces, not chemical bonds. Desorption is the release of adsorbed species. Absorption involves penetration into the bulk, not surface bonding.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of chemisorption?

options.text: It has high enthalpy of adsorption

questions.explanation_correct: Chemisorption results in monolayer formation only, since the adsorbate forms chemical bonds directly with the surface. Multilayer formation is characteristic of physisorption.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chemisorption is indeed highly specific, has high enthalpy of adsorption (80–240 kJ/mol), and is generally irreversible. However, it forms only a monolayer, not multilayers.

questions.question_text: According to the Freundlich adsorption isotherm, x/m = kP^(1/n). At high pressure, 1/n approaches:
questions.explanation_correct: At high pressure, adsorption becomes independent of pressure as the surface gets saturated. In the Freundlich equation, 1/n approaches 0, making x/m = k (a constant).
questions.explanation_incorrect: At low pressure, 1/n approaches 1 (x/m is directly proportional to P). At high pressure, adsorption reaches saturation so x/m becomes constant, meaning 1/n → 0. It does not go to infinity or stay at 0.5.

questions.question_text: Physisorption of a gas increases with:
questions.explanation_correct: Physisorption is an exothermic process. According to Le Chatelier's principle, lowering temperature favours the forward (adsorption) process, so physisorption increases with decrease in temperature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Increase in temperature decreases physisorption (exothermic process). Decrease in surface area reduces available sites for adsorption. Decrease in pressure reduces the number of gas molecules available for adsorption.

questions.question_text: Which of the following gases would be most readily adsorbed on the surface of activated charcoal?
questions.explanation_correct: Easily liquefiable gases with higher critical temperatures are adsorbed more readily. SO₂ has the highest critical temperature among the options and is most easily liquefiable, making it most readily adsorbed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: H₂, N₂, and He are all difficult to liquefy (low critical temperatures). The extent of adsorption is directly related to the critical temperature of the gas — higher critical temperature means easier liquefaction and greater adsorption.

questions.question_text: A substance that increases the rate of a chemical reaction without being consumed is called a:
questions.explanation_correct: A catalyst is a substance that alters (usually increases) the rate of a chemical reaction without itself being consumed in the process. It provides an alternative pathway with lower activation energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A reactant is consumed in the reaction. An inhibitor slows down a reaction. A promoter enhances the activity of a catalyst but is not itself a catalyst.

questions.question_text: In heterogeneous catalysis, the catalytic reaction occurs at the:
questions.explanation_correct: In heterogeneous catalysis, the reactants are adsorbed on the surface of the solid catalyst. The reaction occurs at the surface, where bonds are weakened and new bonds are formed, after which products desorb.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The catalytic action in heterogeneous catalysis specifically occurs at the surface, not in the bulk of the catalyst or reactant. It involves adsorption of reactants on the solid surface, not at a liquid-liquid interface.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of homogeneous catalysis?

options.text: Oxidation of SO₂ to SO₃ in the lead chamber process using NO
Hydrogenation of oils using nickel catalyst

questions.explanation_correct: In the lead chamber process, SO₂ (gas), O₂ (gas), and the catalyst NO (gas) are all in the same gaseous phase, making it an example of homogeneous catalysis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Haber's process (Fe), hydrogenation of oils (Ni), and the contact process (V₂O₅) all use solid catalysts with gaseous reactants — these are examples of heterogeneous catalysis.

questions.question_text: Enzymes are biological catalysts that are highly specific. The lock-and-key model explains this by stating that:

options.text: The enzyme can catalyse any reaction
The active site of the enzyme has a shape complementary to the substrate
Enzymes work only at very high temperatures
Enzymes are consumed during the reaction

questions.explanation_correct: The lock-and-key model states that the active site of an enzyme has a specific shape that is complementary to the substrate, just as a lock accepts only a specific key. This explains enzyme specificity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Enzymes are highly specific, not universal catalysts. They typically work best at moderate temperatures (around 37°C for human enzymes) and are not consumed in the reaction.

questions.question_text: The process of removing adsorbed substance from the surface is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Desorption is the reverse of adsorption — it is the process by which adsorbed molecules leave the surface of the adsorbent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Adsorption is the accumulation on the surface. Absorption involves penetration into the bulk. Sorption is a general term covering both adsorption and absorption. The specific term for removal from the surface is desorption.

questions.question_text: A catalyst poison works by:

options.text: Increasing the surface area of the catalyst
Getting preferentially adsorbed on the active sites of the catalyst
Increasing the activation energy of the reaction
Changing the phase of the catalyst

questions.explanation_correct: A catalyst poison gets preferentially adsorbed on the active sites of the catalyst surface, blocking them and preventing the reactants from being adsorbed. This renders the catalyst ineffective.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Catalyst poisons do not increase surface area (that would enhance catalysis), do not change the activation energy directly, and do not change the phase. They simply block active sites by adsorption.

questions.question_text: The Langmuir adsorption isotherm assumes that:

options.text: Adsorption occurs at definite, equivalent sites forming a monolayer
Adsorption enthalpy varies with surface coverage

questions.explanation_correct: The Langmuir isotherm assumes that adsorption takes place at specific, equivalent, homogeneous sites on the adsorbent surface, forming only a monolayer. There is no interaction between adsorbed molecules.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Langmuir model specifically assumes monolayer adsorption (not multilayer), equivalent sites (not non-equivalent), and constant enthalpy of adsorption regardless of surface coverage.

questions.question_text: Which of the following increases the extent of adsorption?

options.text: Decreasing the surface area of adsorbent
Increasing the surface area of adsorbent
Using an adsorbent with fewer active sites

questions.explanation_correct: Increasing the surface area of the adsorbent provides more sites for adsorption, thus increasing the extent of adsorption. This is why finely divided or porous adsorbents like activated charcoal are used.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Decreasing surface area, using non-porous materials, or having fewer active sites would all reduce the extent of adsorption, not increase it.

questions.question_text: In the Freundlich isotherm equation log(x/m) = log k + (1/n)log P, a plot of log(x/m) versus log P gives a straight line with slope equal to:
questions.explanation_correct: Comparing log(x/m) = log k + (1/n)log P with y = c + mx, the slope of the straight line is 1/n and the intercept is log k.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The equation log(x/m) = log k + (1/n)log P is in the form y = c + mx. Here, log k is the y-intercept, not the slope. The slope is 1/n, not k or n.

questions.question_text: Chemisorption first increases and then decreases with increasing temperature because:

options.text: Initially activation energy is overcome; at very high temperatures, desorption dominates
Van der Waals forces increase with temperature
The adsorbent decomposes at high temperature

questions.explanation_correct: Chemisorption requires activation energy, so it initially increases with temperature as the energy barrier is overcome. At very high temperatures, desorption becomes dominant and the extent of adsorption decreases.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Higher temperature does not always favour adsorption. Van der Waals forces are relevant to physisorption, not chemisorption. The adsorbent does not necessarily decompose — the decrease is due to enhanced desorption.

questions.question_text: The size of colloidal particles lies in the range:
questions.explanation_correct: Colloidal particles have sizes ranging from 1 nm (10⁻⁹ m) to 1000 nm (10⁻⁶ m). Particles smaller than 1 nm form true solutions, and those larger than 1000 nm form suspensions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Particles less than 1 nm constitute true solutions, not colloids. Particles greater than 1000 nm form suspensions. The colloidal range is specifically 1–1000 nm.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a lyophilic colloid?
questions.explanation_correct: Starch solution is a lyophilic (solvent-loving) colloid because starch has strong affinity for water. Lyophilic colloids are reversible and more stable.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gold sol, sulphur sol, and Fe(OH)₃ sol are all lyophobic (solvent-hating) colloids. They have little affinity for the dispersion medium and require stabilising agents.

questions.question_text: The scattering of light by colloidal particles is known as:
questions.explanation_correct: The Tyndall effect is the scattering of a beam of light by colloidal particles, making the path of light visible. This occurs because colloidal particles are large enough to scatter light.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Brownian motion is the random zigzag movement of colloidal particles. Electrophoresis is the movement of particles under an electric field. Dialysis is the purification of colloids using a semipermeable membrane.

questions.question_text: Bredig's arc method is used for the preparation of:

options.text: Colloidal sols of metals like gold, silver, and platinum

questions.explanation_correct: Bredig's arc method involves striking an electric arc between electrodes of the metal immersed in the dispersion medium. This produces colloidal sols of metals such as gold, silver, and platinum.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bredig's arc method is a dispersion method specifically designed for preparing metal sols, not emulsions, true solutions, or suspensions.

questions.question_text: The random zigzag motion of colloidal particles due to bombardment by molecules of the dispersion medium is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Brownian motion is the continuous random zigzag movement of colloidal particles caused by the unequal bombardment of dispersion medium molecules on the colloidal particles from different directions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tyndall effect involves light scattering. Electrophoresis is the directed movement under an electric field. Coagulation is the settling of colloidal particles. The random motion described is Brownian motion.

questions.question_text: According to the Hardy-Schulze rule, which of the following ions would have the greatest coagulating power for a negatively charged colloid?
questions.explanation_correct: The Hardy-Schulze rule states that the greater the valency of the coagulating ion (the ion with charge opposite to the colloid), the greater its coagulating power. For a negatively charged colloid, Al³⁺ (trivalent) has the greatest coagulating power: Al³⁺ > Ba²⁺ > Na⁺ = K⁺.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Na⁺ and K⁺ are monovalent, Ba²⁺ is divalent, and Al³⁺ is trivalent. Since the colloid is negatively charged, the coagulating ion must be positively charged, and higher valency means greater coagulating power.

questions.question_text: The process of converting a freshly prepared precipitate into a colloidal sol by adding a small amount of electrolyte is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Peptization is the process of converting a precipitate into a colloidal sol by shaking it with the dispersion medium in the presence of a small amount of electrolyte (peptizing agent).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Coagulation is the opposite — settling of colloidal particles. Dialysis is the removal of dissolved substances from a colloid. Electrophoresis involves particle movement under an electric field.

questions.question_text: During electrophoresis, positively charged colloidal particles move towards the:
questions.explanation_correct: During electrophoresis, colloidal particles move towards the electrode of opposite charge. Positively charged particles migrate towards the cathode (negative electrode).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Charged particles move towards the oppositely charged electrode. Positively charged colloids are attracted to the negative electrode (cathode), not the positive electrode (anode).

questions.question_text: Which of the following colloidal solutions cannot be prepared by Bredig's arc method?
questions.explanation_correct: Bredig's arc method is used for preparing colloidal sols of metals (Au, Ag, Pt). Sulphur is a non-metal and its sol cannot be prepared by this method — it is prepared by chemical methods like passing H₂S through an oxidising agent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gold, silver, and platinum are all metals whose sols can be prepared by Bredig's arc method. Sulphur is a non-metal, so the electrical arc between sulphur electrodes will not produce a colloidal sol.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of an associated colloid (micelle)?
questions.explanation_correct: Soap molecules form micelles (associated colloids) when dissolved in water above the critical micelle concentration (CMC). Below CMC, they behave as normal electrolytes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gold sol and sulphur sol are lyophobic colloids. Starch is a lyophilic colloid. Soap solution above CMC forms micelles — aggregates of soap molecules that behave as colloidal particles.

questions.question_text: Dialysis is a process used to:

options.text: Remove dissolved substances from colloidal solutions using a semipermeable membrane

questions.explanation_correct: Dialysis is a purification method for colloids in which dissolved ions and small molecules pass through a semipermeable membrane, while colloidal particles (being larger) are retained.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dialysis does not prepare colloids, coagulate particles, or charge particles. It is specifically a purification process that separates crystalloid impurities from colloidal solutions.

questions.question_text: The charge on As₂S₃ sol is due to the adsorption of:
questions.explanation_correct: As₂S₃ sol is prepared by passing H₂S through As₂O₃ solution. The sol particles preferentially adsorb S²⁻ ions (common ions from H₂S), giving them a negative charge.
questions.explanation_incorrect: According to the Fajans rule, colloidal particles preferentially adsorb ions that are common to their own lattice. As₂S₃ adsorbs S²⁻ ions (from excess H₂S), not H⁺, OH⁻, or Na⁺ ions.

questions.question_text: Which property of colloids is used in the purification of water?
questions.explanation_correct: Impurities in water are often colloidal. Alum (potash alum) is added to water to cause coagulation of the negatively charged colloidal impurities by providing Al³⁺ ions, which settles the particles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tyndall effect and Brownian motion are properties of colloids but are not used for water purification. Peptization creates colloids rather than removing them. Coagulation settles colloidal impurities.

questions.question_text: A colloidal solution of Fe(OH)₃ is prepared by adding FeCl₃ to hot water. The charge on the colloidal particles is:
questions.explanation_correct: Fe(OH)₃ sol prepared by hydrolysis of FeCl₃ adsorbs Fe³⁺ ions from the solution, giving the colloidal particles a positive charge. The sol migrates towards the cathode during electrophoresis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fe(OH)₃ sol is positively charged because it preferentially adsorbs Fe³⁺ ions. It is not neutral or negatively charged. The charge is determined by the adsorbed ions, not pH.

questions.question_text: Which of the following methods is a chemical method for preparing colloidal solutions?

options.text: Double decomposition of As₂O₃ with H₂S

questions.explanation_correct: Passing H₂S gas through a solution of As₂O₃ produces As₂S₃ sol by a double decomposition reaction: As₂O₃ + 3H₂S → As₂S₃ (sol) + 3H₂O. This is a chemical method of preparation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bredig's arc method is an electrical dispersion method. Peptization and mechanical dispersion are physical methods. The reaction between As₂O₃ and H₂S is a chemical method.

questions.question_text: The protective action of lyophilic colloids is measured by:
questions.explanation_correct: The gold number, introduced by Zsigmondy, is the minimum weight (in mg) of the protective colloid required to just prevent the coagulation of 10 mL of a standard gold sol when 1 mL of 10% NaCl solution is added. A smaller gold number means better protective action.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Silver number is not a standard term for protective action. Hardy-Schulze rule deals with coagulating power. Kraft temperature relates to surfactants. The gold number specifically measures protective colloid efficiency.

questions.question_text: A multimolecular colloid is formed when:

options.text: A single macromolecule dissolves to form colloidal-sized particles
Many atoms or small molecules aggregate to form colloidal-sized particles

questions.explanation_correct: Multimolecular colloids are formed when many atoms or small molecules aggregate together to form particles of colloidal dimensions. For example, a gold sol consists of clusters of gold atoms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A single macromolecule forming a colloidal particle is a macromolecular colloid (e.g., proteins, polymers). Surfactant aggregation above CMC forms associated colloids (micelles). Polymer dissolution forms macromolecular colloids.

questions.question_text: An emulsion is a colloidal system of:

options.text: A solid dispersed in a liquid
A gas dispersed in a liquid

questions.explanation_correct: An emulsion is a colloidal dispersion of one liquid in another immiscible liquid. The two types are oil-in-water (O/W) and water-in-oil (W/O).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Miscible liquids form true solutions, not emulsions. A solid in liquid is a sol. A gas in liquid is a foam. Emulsions specifically involve two immiscible liquids.

questions.question_text: Milk is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Milk is an oil-in-water (O/W) emulsion where tiny fat globules (oil phase) are dispersed in the aqueous phase (water). The protein casein acts as the emulsifying agent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Milk is not a W/O emulsion (butter is). It is not a gel (which is a semi-rigid system) or a solid sol (e.g., gemstones). Milk has fat droplets dispersed in water, making it an O/W emulsion.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a water-in-oil (W/O) emulsion?
questions.explanation_correct: Butter is a water-in-oil (W/O) emulsion where tiny water droplets are dispersed in the fat (oil) phase. When cream is churned, the O/W emulsion (cream) is converted to a W/O emulsion (butter).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Milk and vanishing cream are oil-in-water (O/W) emulsions. Cod liver oil is typically an O/W emulsion. Butter has water dispersed in fat, making it a W/O emulsion.

questions.question_text: An emulsifier stabilises an emulsion by:

options.text: Increasing the density of the dispersion medium
Forming a protective film at the interface between the two liquids
Removing one of the liquid phases

questions.explanation_correct: An emulsifier (emulsifying agent) forms a protective interfacial film around the dispersed droplets, preventing them from coalescing. This stabilises the emulsion and prevents the two phases from separating.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Emulsifiers do not change density, increase temperature, or remove liquid phases. They work by positioning themselves at the interface between the two liquids, forming a stabilising film.

questions.question_text: A gel is a colloidal system in which:

options.text: A gas is dispersed in a solid
A liquid is dispersed in a solid forming a semi-rigid structure
A solid is dispersed in a gas
A liquid is dispersed in a gas

questions.explanation_correct: A gel is a colloidal system in which a liquid is the dispersed phase and a solid forms the network of the dispersion medium, creating a semi-rigid, jelly-like structure. Examples include gelatin, cheese, and silica gel.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A gas dispersed in a solid is a solid foam. A solid in gas is an aerosol. A liquid in gas is also an aerosol (like fog). Gels specifically have liquid trapped in a solid network.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an application of colloids in medicine?

options.text: Argyrol and protargol used as eye lotions
Formation of delta at river mouths

questions.explanation_correct: Argyrol and protargol are colloidal solutions of silver used as antiseptic eye lotions. This is a direct medical application of colloidal chemistry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Smoke precipitation is an industrial application. Cleansing action of soap is a domestic application. Delta formation is a natural phenomenon. The medical application among these is the use of colloidal silver in eye lotions.

questions.question_text: The formation of delta at river mouths is due to:

options.text: Coagulation of colloidal particles of river water by the electrolytes in sea water
Tyndall effect of light in water

questions.explanation_correct: River water contains colloidal clay and sand particles. When river water meets sea water (which contains electrolytes like NaCl, MgCl₂), the colloidal particles are coagulated and deposited, forming a delta.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Delta formation is not due to peptization (which creates colloids), Brownian motion, or Tyndall effect. It is caused by coagulation of the colloidal particles in river water by the electrolytes present in sea water.

questions.question_text: The Cottrell precipitator works on the principle of:

options.text: Electrophoresis — charged smoke particles are neutralised and precipitated

questions.explanation_correct: The Cottrell precipitator uses the principle of electrophoresis. Smoke particles (colloidal) carry an electric charge. When passed through a chamber with charged plates, the particles are neutralised, coagulated, and precipitated.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Cottrell precipitator does not rely on Brownian motion, Tyndall effect, or peptization. It uses electrically charged plates to neutralise and precipitate charged smoke particles — a principle related to electrophoresis.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of a gel?
questions.explanation_correct: Cheese is an example of a gel — a semi-rigid colloidal system in which a liquid (whey) is trapped within a solid protein network. Other examples include gelatin and jelly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Milk is an emulsion (O/W). Fog is an aerosol (liquid in gas). Smoke is an aerosol (solid in gas). Cheese is a gel with liquid trapped in a solid network.

questions.question_text: Which of the following emulsifiers would favour the formation of an oil-in-water emulsion?

options.text: Heavy metal salts of fatty acids

questions.explanation_correct: Water-soluble emulsifiers like proteins and gums favour the formation of O/W emulsions. They are more soluble in the aqueous phase and stabilise the oil droplets dispersed in water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Heavy metal salts of fatty acids and long-chain alcohols are oil-soluble and favour W/O emulsions. Lampblack can act as a stabiliser but is not a typical O/W emulsifier. Water-soluble emulsifiers favour O/W emulsions.

questions.question_text: The cleansing action of soap is due to:
questions.explanation_correct: Soap molecules form micelles in water. The hydrophobic tail dissolves in grease/oil while the hydrophilic head remains in water. This emulsifies the grease into tiny droplets (micelles), which are washed away.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Soap does not form a true solution with grease. It does not coagulate dirt or peptize grease. The cleansing action is based on emulsification — grease is trapped inside micelles and removed.

questions.question_text: Elastic gels (like gelatin) differ from non-elastic gels (like silica gel) in that elastic gels:

options.text: Change volume on absorbing liquid and regain original form on drying

questions.explanation_correct: Elastic gels (like gelatin) swell by absorbing the liquid (imbibition) and change volume. On drying, they return to their original form and can be reconverted to gel by adding liquid. Non-elastic gels (like silica gel) do not change form.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Elastic gels can imbibe water (that is their key property). They are not necessarily transparent. They can be reformed on adding liquid, unlike non-elastic gels which remain rigid.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT an application of colloids?
questions.explanation_correct: Electroplating is an electrochemical process that involves deposition of metal ions from a true solution, not a colloidal process. Water purification (coagulation), photography (AgBr colloid), and rubber plating (latex coagulation) all involve colloid chemistry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Water purification uses coagulation of colloidal impurities. Photographic films use colloidal AgBr in gelatin. Rubber plating uses coagulation of rubber latex. Electroplating is not a colloidal application.

questions.question_text: An emulsion can be broken (demulsified) by:

options.text: Heating, freezing, centrifuging, or adding electrolytes

questions.explanation_correct: Emulsions can be broken (demulsified) by heating, freezing, centrifuging, or adding electrolytes or a chemical that destroys the emulsifier. These methods destabilise the interfacial film.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Adding more emulsifier would stabilise the emulsion further. Dilution would not break the emulsion. Simply cooling to room temperature is not an effective method. Breaking requires disrupting the stabilising film.

questions.question_text: Colloidal medicines are more effective because:

options.text: They have a larger surface area and are easily assimilated
They do not interact with body tissues

questions.explanation_correct: Colloidal medicines are more effective because their small particle size gives them a very large surface area, which enhances absorption and assimilation in the body. They are easily absorbed by body tissues.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The effectiveness of colloidal medicines is not related to taste, cost, or lack of interaction. It is due to the large surface area of colloidal particles, which promotes rapid and efficient absorption.

questions.question_text: Which type of emulsion is formed when a water-soluble emulsifier is used?
questions.explanation_correct: A water-soluble emulsifier (such as proteins, gum arabic, or sodium stearate) preferentially stabilises oil-in-water (O/W) emulsions, where oil is dispersed in the continuous aqueous phase.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Water-soluble emulsifiers favour O/W emulsions, not W/O. Oil-soluble emulsifiers (like heavy metal salts of fatty acids) favour W/O emulsions. The solubility of the emulsifier determines the type of emulsion formed.
